## 
```{r}
data("nuc_airbnb")

nyc_airbnb = 
  nyc_airbnb %>% 
  mutate(stars = review_scores_location / 2) %>% 
  rename(
    borough = neighbourhood_group,
    neighbourhood = neighbourhood) %>% 
  filter(borough != "Staten Island") %>% 
  select(price, stars, borough, neighbourhood, room_type) 
```

## Fit a model 

```{r}
nyc_airbnb %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stars, y = price, color = borough)) +
  geom_point()
```

Let's fit a model we care about 

```{r}
fit = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)
```

Lets look at the results 

```{r, include = FALSE}
fit

summary(fit)
summary(fit)$coef
coef(fit)
fitted.values(fit)
residuals(fit)
```

Let's look at the results better and changing from matrix to a dataframe

```{r}
broom::glance(fit)

broom::tidy(fit) %>% 
  select(-std.error, -statistic) %>% 
  mutate(
    term = str_replace(term, "borough", "Borough:")
        ) %>% 
      knitr::kable(digits = 3)
```

## Be in controls of factors 

```{r}
nyc_airbnb =
  nyc_airbnb %>% 
  mutate(
    borough = fct_infreq(borough),
    room_type = fct_infreq(room_type)
  )
```

look at the plot again 

```{r}
nyc_airbnb %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stars, y = price, color = borough)) +
  geom_point()
```

Refit the model 

```{r}
fit = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)

broom::tidy(fit)
broom::glance(fit)
```


## Diagnostics

```{r}
modelr::add_residuals(nyc_airbnb, fit) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = borough, y = resid)) +
  geom_violin() +
  ylim(-500, 1500)

nyc_airbnb %>% 
  modelr::add_residuals(fit) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stars, y = resid)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(. ~ borough)
  
```

This regrssion diagnostic shows problems with the regression. We need to go back and check our hypothesis and the type of regression chosen. 

## Hypothesis testing 

THIS DOES T-TEST BY DEFAULT 
```{r}
fit %>% 
  broom::tidy()
  
```

what about the significance of the borough 

We need to do an ANOVA 

```{r}
fit_null = lm(price ~ stars, data = nyc_airbnb)
fit_alt = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)

anova(fit_null, fit_alt) %>% 
  broom::tidy()
```

## Nest data and fit models 

This is formal
```{r}
fit = lm(price ~ stars * borough + room_type * borough, data = nyc_airbnb)

broom::tidy(fit)
```

This is more exploratory 
what is the effect of stars in brooklyn, Manhattan and queens? 
Fit different models -

```{r}
nyc_airbnb %>% 
  nest(data = -borough) %>% 
  mutate(
    models = map(.x = data, ~lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = .x)),
    results = map(models, broom::tidy)
  ) %>%  
  select(-data, -models) %>% 
  unnest(results) %>% 
  filter(term != "(Intercept)") %>% 
  select(borough, term, estimate) %>% 
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = borough,
    values_from = estimate
  )
```

Let's nest even more 
Look at the same within the neighbourhood in Manhattan.

```{r}
nyc_airbnb %>%
  filter(borough == "Manhattan") %>% 
  nest(data = -neighbourhood) %>% 
  mutate(
    models = map(.x = data, ~ lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = .x)),
    results = map(models, broom::tidy)
  ) %>% 
  select(-data, -models) %>%
  unnest(results) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(term, "room_type")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = neighbourhood, y = estimate)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(. ~ term) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 70, vjust = 0.5, hjust = 1))
```
